awd_titl_txt: Analysis and Control of Mathematical Models of Fluttering Plates
awd_abstract_narration:
One of the fundamental problems in the field of aeroelasticity is the prediction and control of the instability known as aeroelastic flutter. Flutter occurs in a flexible structure immersed in a gas flow when aerodynamic loading excites the natural oscillatory modes of the structure; the result is a potentially violent interaction between the displacements of the structure and perturbations in the gas flow field. This phenomenon may occur in a multitude of applications including: buildings and bridges in strong winds, flag-like structures, the human respiratory system, and panel and flap structures on air and land vehicles. In the context of aircraft, flutter is a key concern. If the magnitude of the structural displacements due to flutter is sufficiently large, structural failure can occur. Small oscillations sustained over long periods of time may also bring about costly and/or hazardous fatigue in the structure. Very recently, the idea of harnessing flutter (naturally occurring, or induced) has been suggested to provide an alternative source of energy via piezoelectric "harvesting". For these reasons there is great interest in producing mathematical models that describe the flutter phenomenon in order to gain insight into the mechanisms of flow-structure coupling and predict the dynamics of the system based on its physical parameters. This project comprises a control of partial differential equations (PDEs) analysis of the principal model associated to panel and flap flutter. Results derived from PDE analyses are valuable for a variety of reasons. They: (i) guide and streamline experimental and numerical flutter threshold determination, (ii) can improve cost-effectiveness of experimentation and cut-down on design time of prototypes, (iii) indicate what types and locations of damping will be effective for a given flow-plate configuration. 

The proposed investigations are based upon very recent progress in aeroelasticity that has permitted extensions of a classical flow-plate model used over the last 50 years. Obtaining results for flow-structure systems is demanding, as problems arise in the mismatching regularity of dynamics at the interface and ill defined or unbounded trace terms in the coupling. Recent advances in hyperbolic trace regularity theory, abstract coupled models, PDEs with delay, and geometrically constrained damping make modern PDE analysis of flow-plate models tractable. This proposal centers on well-posedness and stability in the presence of feedback controls for a class of nonlinear flow-plate models which include partially free plate boundary conditions and dynamic flow boundary conditions near plate edges. Fully nonlinear models accounting for both in-plane and out-of-plane motion in the structure, as well as nonlinear fluids, are considered. Moreover, recent stability analyses will be extended to the intermediary "transonic" flow regime and the piston-theoretic, hypersonic regime. Beyond well-posedness of these models, time convergence properties (i.e., attractors) of the dynamics will be considered to determine the sensitivity of non-transient behavior of the system to the plate's boundary conditions and external loading. The current proposal can be viewed as an analysis of models arising in aeroelasticity by providing a comparison between qualitative properties of well-posed PDEs to experimentally observed and/or numerically approximated behaviors.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
The interactive dynamics between a fluid and a solid at a boundary interface is known as a fluid-structure interaction (FSI). FSI models are abundant in the applied sciences and have been a topic of immense research interest for 60 years. Theoretical, numerical, and experimental scientists are interested in characterizing, predicting, and controlling their behavior. The outcomes of this grant concerned partial differential equation (PDE) models for fluttering structures in application. Flutter is a sustained, systemic instability which occurs as a potentially violent feedback between a thin structure and a surrounding fluid flow when the natural elastic modes of the structure "couple" with the aerodynamic load. This phenomenon is of great interest in fields that concern flight. When a structure is immersed in a fluid flow, certain velocities may bring about a fundamental change in the dynamics, which may become oscillatory, or even chaotic. This can occur in a multitude of applications, including: buildings and bridges in wind, paneling and flap structures on vehicles, and in the human respiratory system (snoring and sleep apnea). Recently, the flutter of a small cantilever has been studied from the point of view of piezoelectric energy harvesting.


Specific to flight, understanding FSI models and associated control strategies can make air travel safer, more cost-effective by improving range, and lower aircraft operating costs by reducing sustained fatigue. From a design point of view, flutter cannot be overlooked owing to its potentially disastrous effects on the structure due to sustained fatigue or large amplitude response. The field of aeroelasticity is concerned with (i) producing models which describe the flutter phenomenon, (ii) gaining insight into the mechanisms of flow-structure coupling, (iii) predicting the behavior of a flow-structure system based on its physical parameters and configuration, and (iv) determining appropriate control mechanisms and their effect in the prevention or suppression of instability in the flow-structure system.  


Given the difficulty of modeling coupled PDEs at an interface, theoretical results on flutter have been sparse. Additionally, post-flutter dynamics are inherently nonlinear, further complicating analysis. While computational studies address various situations, they are based on finite-dimensional approximations of a continuum model fully described by PDEs. The true nature of the physical phenomena may not be adequately reflected by these approximations. The main point of this grant was to place the flutter phenomenon (and associated unstable dynamics) on a rigorous footing; the results from this grant have demonstrated that the FSI model can be studied from an unsimplified point of view, and that meaningful statements can be made about the physical mechanisms of FSIs directly from a PDE models. 

 
The PI believes that PDE and control analyses of these models belong alongside numerical and experimental work being done on flutter and flow-plate interactions. Specifically, theoretical results provide corroboration, and in some cases scrutiny, for the PDE models themselves. This is seen at the level of qualitative behavior of solutions to the coupled FSI PDE systems. Strictly at the level of the equations, without utilizing numerical or approximate techniques, the following results have been obtained: 


1.) Nonlinearity is needed for predicting the magnitude of structural oscillations (providing rigorous bounds on solutions). 

2.) Developing a rigorous treatment of the appropriate flow condition for a fluttering cantilever (the Kutta Joukowsky condition); this configuration is poorly understood and pertinent both to flight and energy harvesting.

3.) Nonlinear modeling issues associated with energy harvesting beam models for axial flow cantilevers have been resolved.

4.) An understanding of von Karman nonlinear elasticity theory with dissipative forces acting through the boundary was obtained.(This includes new numerical simulations of full von Karman dynamics.)

5.) A clear understanding of the effect of control-theoretic interior damping for flow-plate models was obtained, including the impact on global and exponential attractors.

6.) A clear mathematical comprehension of the stabilizing effects of the flow in the subsonic regime and destabilizing effects in the supersonic regime was obtained. In the subsonic case, with any amount of mechanical damping, the limiting behavior of panels in subsonic flows is stationary. 

7.) Cross-disciplinary work between engineers, computational scientists, and applied mathematicians was performed to unify these varied points of view.

8.) The non-transient behavior of flow-plate dynamics appears as an inherently finite-dimensional phenomenon. We can provide a bound on the dimension of the set which characterizes limiting dynamics. This is a rigorous “reduction” of the dynamics.




Last Modified: 11/12/2017
Modified by: Justin T Webster
